data: Build personal relationship

I spend a lot of time just explaining some aspects of the nature of our particular business that no one had ever discussed with them before, to give them a more nuanced understanding.

I discuss with my mentee how best to approach requests for time off from subordinates and when the best timing of that would be to maintain efficient workflow.
I discuss with my mentee ways that people handle working with others located in different time zones and managing it to minimize inconvenience.
With my mentee's permission, we review their performance evaluations together to get a clear picture of how they were being evaluated internally.

I review (according to standards) what my mentee had been doing on a project up to this point to get a sense of whether they would be able to take on more responsibilities without additional help or training.
I review my mentee's business plan to see if it was complete and clear.
I monitor my mentee's performance in real time when I can, so it will be a live learning experience and that the feedback I provide can happen when it was 'still warm.'

Following a failed attempt at a task by my mentee, I ask them directly how they would approach the task differently the next time.
I provide feedback in a kind and constructive way during one-on-one meetings at regular intervals during each part of a long-term project.

I adjust the mode of providing feedback so that more technical questions can be addressed in a brief email, but more complex issues, such as navigating politics and reading social cues, are given face to face.

When I provide constructive feedback I always stress what my mentee could do differently in the future and why, with a clear explanation of why it would be helpful. I note the speed at which I give feedback and the amount of information I provide so that it is detailed enough to be clear and slow enough to be heard and absorbed.

After a mentee turned in subpar work that I knew was below their talent level, I directly tell them that I knew they could do much better and would have to work to their capability, rather than indicating in any way that I doubted their talent based on that work.

After closely monitoring a mentee's work on a particular task and not seeing improvement, I tell them that I need to let them work on it themselves because the organization needed them to feel comfortable working on it independently and that wouldn't happen if I was always there.
When I sense my mentee feels underappreciated, I compliment them by telling they are capable and not as highly valued by others as they actually are.
When my mentee was very late for a meeting because of traffic, I gently but firmly pointed out that if it was a job interview, they would not be considered.
I directly let my mentee know when I do not think something is correct, but if they are sure about it I stand behind their choices, as ultimately they are in charge of their choices.

Even if it isn't comfortable, I give feedback directly on my mentee's professionalism, including appearance and communication style, being gentle but direct and letting them know why something is not appropriate and how it can be adjusted.
